title: House spiders catch and devour their prey in incredible close-up pictures
text:
Arachnophobes may disagree - but these incredibly detailed pictures of spiders catching and eating their prey are pretty awe-inspiring.
And, worryingly, every one of them was found in a house.
One of the most terrifying images shows a spider, with its eyes bulging and its thick hairy legs wrapped around its unfortunate victim.
It's just one in a series designed to shed a new light on the eight-legged creatures.
Photographer Sam Donato captured different species of spiders at his house in Nashville, US.
Sam spent hours waiting for the arachnids to reveal their natural behaviour, using extension tubes and reverse mounted prime lenses to track the tiny beasts ' lives.
Barcroft Gotcha! A female Phidippus mystaceus spider catches a fly
Barcroft You're going nowhere, pal: A female Phidippus otiosus spider catches an insect
He said: “The main problem with macro photography is that the subject must stay very still.
“An unoccupied spider, even if they are happy with their surroundings will move to clean themselves or sense their surroundings.
Barcroft Close-up: A male Phidippus mystaceus spider holds on to a fly
Barcroft She lives in your house: A female Phidippus mystaceus spider grips on to a housefly
Barcroft In a different light: A female Phidippus mystaceus spider prepares to devour a fly
“As it began, I was scared and they were scared. I was impatient and they were impatient and as in any relationship, we had to learn to compromise and get along.
“What I found was that spiders are wonderful and curious creatures. If you make them comfortable and not threatened, they are delighted to sit and watch the lens.
Barcroft No more holes: A female Phidippus mystaceus spider tears down a moth
Barcroft Terrifying sight: A Metacyrba taeniola spider catches a fly
“Spiders like to practice their amazing jumping ability, walk around on your hands and even let you pet them.
“These pictures are amazingly beautiful and they make me realise how wonderful these spiders are. The more I click them, the more I feel close to them.”
